meta.title: Neuroendocrine (Endocrine Neoplasm of Pancreas & Carcinoid Tumour)

questions.text: All are true about adenocarcinoma of the lung except:

options.label: B
options.text: Incidence is more common in women

options.label: D
options.text: Typically appears as a cavitating tumor

questions.correct_answer: D. Typically appears as a cavitating tumor
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Typically appears as a cavitating tumor Histological classification of lung cancer: Small cell lung cancers were known as oat cell cancers because of the packed nature of small dense cells. They are a type of neuroendocrine tumor (NET) and represent about 20% of all lung cancers. They tend to metastasize early to lymph nodes and by blood-borne spread. The median survival is measured in months. The tumors are very responsive to chemotherapy such that median survival may be doubled (although it is still short) but they are rarely, if ever, cured. Surgery is rarely offered unless in very limited-stage disease. Adenocarcinoma is now the most common of the NSCLC types , having overtaken squamous cancer. The increasing incidence is partly due to an increased incidence in women and may be the result, in part, of a ward lower-tar cigarettes that are inhaled more deeply to get the same effect. Squamous carcinoma typically appears as a cavitating tumor. Large cell undifferentiated is a discrete histological type of NSCLC and is included within NETs .

questions.text: Extragonadal germ cell tumor is most commonly found in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior mediastinum Germ cell tumor: The anterior mediastinum is the most common site of extragonadal germ cell tumors. They account for 13% of all mediastinal masses and cysts and contain elements from all three cell types (mesoderm, endoderm, and ectoderm). They tend to present in young adults and 75% are benign and cystic , although they may cause compression of neighboring structures; hence, dermoid cysts are best excised. Malignancy is suspected if elevated levels of serum alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, and carcinoembryonic antigen are detected. After initial treatment with chemotherapy , a patient with tumor marker normalization and a persistent mass on CT may be considered for surgical resection. If tumor markers fail to normalize, further chemotherapy is usually offered.

Highyeild:

The primary tumors of the mediastinum are: Neurogenic tumors Thymoma Lymphoma Germ cell tumors

questions.text: Which of the following is prevalent in the Posterior mediastinum?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neurogenic tumors Neurogenic tumors: These may derive from the sympathetic nervous system or the peripheral nerves and are more prevalent in the posterior mediastinum. They may be painful but are more often discovered accidentally on routine chest radiography and can be quite large. They include neuroblastoma in childhood , and Schwannomas and neurofibromas in adults , which are usually benign. Pheochromocytoma arises from the sympathetic chain and produces the characteristic endocrine syndrome. Excision of neurogenic tumors is generally recommended, particularly if the patient is developing symptoms. This can be performed through a thoracotomy , though for smaller tumors a VATS (Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery) approach can be used.

Highyeild:

Masses in the mediastinum The most common anterior mediastinal mass is thymoma . The most common middle mediastinal mass is a cyst , with the pericardial cyst being the most common. The most common posterior mediastinal mass is neurogenic tumors. Neurogenic tumors are the most common mediastinal mass overall. Lymphoma, bronchogenic cysts, and mesenchymal tumors can be seen in all three compartments of the mediastinum.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Mesenchymal tumors : Lipomas are common in the anterior mediastinum. Other mesenchymal tumors are very rare. Option: B. Thyroid: Ectopic thyroid (and parathyroid) tissue may be found in the anterior mediastinum but usually the mass is an extension of a thyroid lesion (retrosternal goiter). Excision of retrosternal thyroids may be required if there is local airway compression and stridor and can be performed via a Transcervical incision, but occasionally median sternotomy may be required. Option: D. Lymphoma is a common cause of a mediastinal mass lesion, particularly in the anterior mediastinum, and can lead to superior vena cava obstruction or other symptoms of local compression. The main treatment is chemotherapy, & surgery is rarely required apart from obtaining tissue for diagnosis.

Extraedge:

CT is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of mediastinal masses (except for neurogenic tumors). MRI is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of neurogenic tumors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came to the emergency with blurred vision, excessive sweating, and confusion, and after that, she lost consciousness. Her heart rate was 100/min, her blood pressure was 100/70mmHg, and her Random Blood Sugar was 40mg/dL. She was given IV glucose and there was resolution in her symptoms. What is the gold standard tool for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

72-Hour Fasting test She was presented with a typical clinical syndrome known as Whipple’s triad. The gold standard for diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour monitored fast . The triad consists of: Symptomatic fasting hypoglycemia , A documented serum glucose level <50 mg/dl , and Relief of symptoms with the administration of glucose . The gold standard for diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour monitored fast . Blood samples for measurement of plasma glucose, insulin, C-peptide, proinsulin, and beta-hydroxybutyrate should be taken every 6 hours until the glucose concentration is below 60 mg/dL. After this, blood sampling should occur every 1 to 2 hours.

Highyeild:

Whipple's triad includes: Serum glucose level <50 mg/dL Relief of symptoms with glucose administration Symptoms like palpitations, trembling, confusion, and seizure may be present Patients may experience syncopal episodes or less severe symptoms that can be alleviated with frequent eating

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . CT scan detects the disease in only 33% of cases Option: B. For preoperative localization of an insulinoma, Endoscopic Ultrasound has the highest sensitivity and should be used if laparoscopic resection is considered. Option: D. Visceral angiography with venous sampling is rarely required to accurately localize the tumor as Endoscopic Ultrasound has the highest sensitivity.

Extraedge:

Insulinomas can be localized with CT scanning and EUS. EUS has a >90% success rate in the preoperative identification of insulinomas. Visceral angiography with venous sampling is rarely needed for tumor localization. Insulinomas are evenly distributed throughout the pancreas. 90% of insulinomas are benign and solitary, while only 10% are malignant. MEN1 -associated insulinomas are more likely to be multifocal and have a higher recurrence rate.

questions.text: A patient with the Classic Whipple’s triad was found to have factitiously elevated Insulin levels on a 72-Hr fasting test. What about the treatment option of the given condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: If intra-operative Ultrasound is unable to localize the tumor, blind resection is carried out.

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor enucleation is the technique of choice. It can be open or Laparoscopic for special cases.

options.label: C
options.text: Distal pancreatectomy can be done for tumors in close proximity to the pancreatic duct.

options.label: D
options.text: If no lesion is seen in Endoscopic USG, laparotomy is carried out with Intra-Operative USG.

questions.correct_answer: A. If intra-operative Ultrasound is unable to localize the tumor, blind resection is carried out.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If intra-operative Ultrasound is unable to localize the tumor, blind resection is carried out. This is an insulin-producing tumor of the pancreas causing the clinical scenario known as Whipple’s triad . Surgical cure rates in patients with the biochemical diagnosis of insulinoma range from 90% to 100%. If intra-operative Ultrasound (IOUS) is unable to localize the tumor, blind resection is not done , so as to preserve pancreatic function and reduce the risk of iatrogenic diabetes mellitus

Highyeild:

Whipple’s triad includes: Serum glucose level <50 mg/dL Relief of symptoms with glucose administration Symptoms like palpitations, trembling, confusion, and seizure may be present Patients may experience syncopal episodes or less severe symptoms that can be alleviated with frequent eating

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Tumor enucleation is the technique of choice. Laparoscopic surgeries are reserved only for superficial tumors . Option: C . Distal pancreatectomy can be done for tumors located deep in the body or tail of the pancreas or those in close proximity to the pancreatic duct. Option: D . IOUS is used to confirm the presence of a tumor, to find non-palpable lesions, and also to identify the relation of the tumor to the pancreatic duct

Extraedge:

Insulinomas can be localized with CT scanning and EUS. EUS has a >90% success rate in the preoperative identification of insulinomas. Visceral angiography with venous sampling is rarely needed for tumor localization. Insulinomas are evenly distributed throughout the pancreas. 90% of insulinomas are benign and solitary, while only 10% are malignant. MEN1 -associated insulinomas are more likely to be multifocal and have a higher recurrence rate.

questions.text: Which is the most common tumor associated with this demarcated area?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastrinoma The image shown is that of the Gastrinoma triangle . Also known as Passaro’s triangle . The typical location of a Gastrinoma is described by this anatomic region, including the head of the pancreas, duodenum, and the lymphatic bed posterior and superior to the duodenum.

Highyeild:

With elevated Gastrin levels, and the presence of a 7 mm duodenal gastrinoma, the patient is likely suffering from Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES). PPIs can effectively control acid secretion, eliminating the need for total gastrectomy and other acid-reducing surgeries. In cases of ZES in MEN-1, hyperparathyroidism should be treated first and neck exploration performed before removing the gastrinoma. Distal pancreatectomy is used to treat gastrinomas in the body or tail of the pancreas. Pancreaticoduodenectomy is the treatment of choice for gastrinomas located in the head of the pancreas.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . More than 85% of pancreatic cancers are ductal adenocarcinomas. Ductal adenocarcinomas arise most commonly in the head of the Pancreas. Option: C . Virtually all insulinomas are located in the pancreas and tumors are equally distributed within the gland. Option: D . The biliary confluence ( Hilar cholangiocarcinoma or Klatskin tumors ) accounts for 60% of cases of Cholangiocarcinoma.

Extraedge:

Surgery is not advised for MEN 1/gastrinoma patients with tumors <2 cm. Enucleation is preferred for tumors >2 cm. Parathyroidectomy decreases gastric acid secretion.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented to the clinic with abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has had this complaint for some time and has received treatment for it before as well. On further evaluation, he was found to have fulminating ulcer diathesis in the duodenum and was found to have a biochemical diagnosis of Gastrinoma. What is this presentation referred to as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is caused by a Gastrinoma, an endocrine tumor that secretes gastrin, leading to acid hypersecretion and peptic ulceration. Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a condition that includes: Fulminating ulcer diathesis in the stomach, duodenum or atypical sites; Recurrent ulceration despite ‘adequate’ therapy; and Non-beta islet cell tumors of the pancreas (gastrinoma).

Highyeild:

With elevated Gastrin levels, and the presence of a 7 mm duodenal gastrinoma, the patient is likely suffering from Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES). PPIs can effectively control acid secretion, eliminating the need for total gastrectomy and other acid-reducing surgeries. In cases of ZES in MEN-1, hyperparathyroidism should be treated first and neck exploration performed before removing the gastrinoma. Distal pancreatectomy is used to treat gastrinomas in the body or tail of the pancreas. Pancreaticoduodenectomy is the treatment of choice for gastrinomas located in the head of the pancreas.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Whipple’s triad is: Symptomatic fasting hypoglycemia, a documented serum glucose level < 50 mg/dl, and relief of symptoms with the administration of glucose Option: C. Carcinoid Syndrome constitutes: Sudden painful reddening of the face and chest (‘flushing’), diarrhea, &/or bronchospasm. Option: D. The Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide-Secreting Tumour (VIPoma) Syndrome is also called WDHA syndrome due to the presence of watery diarrhea, hypokalaemia, and achlorhydria.

Extraedge:

Provocative tests are helpful if ZES diagnosis is uncertain Provocative diagnostic tests for ZES include: secretin, calcium, secretin-plus-calcium, bombesin, and protein meal tests A secretin stimulation test is considered the best option Secretin provocation test shows ZES if gastrin value increases by >200 pg/mL after secretin administration.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man under treatment for Diabetes mellitus came with a migratory rash, which is seen on the lower abdomen, perineum, perioral area, and feet. The patient also complains of an enlarged, sensitive tongue. Which of the following test are needed for confirmation of diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serum Glucagon Levels. Diabetes in association with dermatitis should raise the suspicion of a Glucagonoma . The CLASSIC necrolytic migratory erythema manifests as cyclic migrations of lesions with spreading margins and healing centers typically on the lower abdomen, perineum, perioral area, and feet. Serum Glucagon Levels help to diagnose Gastrinoma.

Highyeild:

Diabetes with dermatitis may indicate a glucagonoma. Diabetes is typically mild. Necrolytic migratory erythema (NME) is a key symptom, with cyclic migrations of lesions and healing centers. Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring serum glucagon levels (>500 pg/mL). Glucagonoma is associated with malnutrition due to catabolic hormone effects. The rash may be caused by low amino acid levels.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Serum Insulin, C-peptide Levels help to diagnose Insulinoma. Option: C. Serum ACTH levels help in the diagnosis of ACTH-dependent Cushing. Option: D. Serum Gastrin Levels help in the diagnosis of Gastrinoma.

Extraedge:

Preoperative treatment includes controlling diabetes, parenteral nutrition, and octreotide. Glucagonomas are usually found in the body and tail of the pancreas and tend to be large with metastases. Debulking surgery is recommended for symptom relief in good operative candidates.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with abdominal pain, peptic ulcer disease, and severe esophagitis to the clinic. The surgeon suspects Zollinger-Ellison syndrome and wants to be sure of the Diagnosis. Which of the following tests would be required for the most appropriate DIAGNOSIS and LOCALIZATION of the disease? CT scan MRI Serum Glucagon Levels Secretin Stimulation Test Serum Gastrin Levels Endoscopic Ultrasound Somatostatin Receptor Scintigraphy (SRS) Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4, 5, 6, and 7 If the patient presents with a gastric pH below 2.5 and a serum gastrin concentration above 1000 pg/mL ( normal <100pg/mL ) then the diagnosis of ZES is confirmed. In equivocal cases, when the gastrin level is not markedly elevated, a secretin stimulation test is helpful. On the basis of recent studies, either endoscopic ultrasound or CT and somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) scan should be performed preoperatively for staging.

Highyeild:

Hypergastrinemia & increased gastric acid confirms ZES diagnosis Elevated gastrin alone is not enough for diagnosis, basal gastric acid hypersecretion must be shown ZES patients have fasting serum gastrin level >100 pg/mL (100% of cases) BAO >15 mEq/hr in most patients, >5 mEq/hr in those with prior gastric acid surgery Gastrin level >1000 pg/mL is diagnostic for ZES Elevated serum gastrin & gastric aspirate pH <2 almost confirm ZES diagnosis. Statement 1. CT detected Gastrinoma in about 39% of cases. The test of choice is SSTR (octreotide) scintigraphy in combination with CT or EUS. Statement 2. MRI detected Gastrinoma in about 46% of cases. MRI can be used, but routine guidelines prefer CT or EUS. Statement 3. Serum Glucagon is a part of the evaluation for Glucagonoma. Statement 4. Secretin Stimulation Test, causing >200 point increase in Glucagon level is confirmatory for diagnosis. Statement 5. Serum Gastrin levels above 1000 pg/mL are confirmatory for the diagnosis of ZES. Statement 6. Endoscopic Ultrasound detected Gastrinoma in about 80–90% of cases Statement 7. SRS should be performed because almost all Gastrinoma express somatostatin receptors.

Extraedge:

Provocative tests are helpful if ZES diagnosis is uncertain Provocative diagnostic tests for ZES include: secretin, calcium, secretin-plus-calcium, bombesin, and protein meal tests Secretin stimulation test is considered the best option Secretin provocation test shows ZES if gastrin value increases by >200 pg/mL after secretin administration.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man came to the surgical OPD with a complaint of pain in his abdomen. He was found to have Jaundice. On Imaging, a CT scan detects a mass at the head of the Pancreas. The following points can help to distinguish a Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumour from Pancreatic Cancer, EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Pancreatic cancer shows Hypodensity & there are no calcifications seen in a CT scan.

options.label: B
options.text: Chromogranin A in the blood is POSITIVE in Non-functioning Endocrine Tumors.

options.label: C
options.text: Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumors are <5cm in size.

options.label: D
options.text: Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is POSITIVE for Non-functioning Endocrine Tumor.

questions.correct_answer: C. Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumors are <5cm in size.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumors are <5cm in size. Differentiation from the more aggressive pancreatic adenocarcinoma is extremely important. Recognition of NF-PETs is imperative because of their resectability and excellent long-term survival compared with their exocrine counterparts

Highyeild:

Differences between pancreatic cancer and non-functioning endocrine pancreatic tumors (NF-PETs): Pancreatic cancer NF-PETS Tumour size <5 cm >5 cm CT scan Hypodensity Hyperdensity No calcifications Calcifications possible Chromogranin A in blood Negative Positive Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy Negative Positive

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Pancreatic cancer shows Hypodensity & there are no calcifications seen in a CT scan. Option: B. Chromogranin A in the blood is POSITIVE in Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumors. Option: C. Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumors are >5cm in size Option: D. Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is POSITIVE for Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumors.

Extraedge:

Feature Pancreatic Cancer Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumor Definition A malignant growth of cells in the pancreas An abnormal mass of non-functioning endocrine cells in the pancreas CT Scan Findings Hypodensity with no calcifications Not specified Blood Test Not specified Positive for Chromogranin A Tumor Size Not specified <5cm

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a case of Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumour, he was planned for surgery after the localization of the lesion. What is NOT TRUE regarding the treatment of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Radical Surgery is done with curative intent, especially in cases where complete resection is a possibility.

options.label: B
options.text: Repeated resections for resectable recurrences or metastases are justified to improve survival.

options.label: C
options.text: Partial Pancreaticoduodenectomy is usually performed. as well as the synchronous or metachronous resection of liver metastases.

options.label: D
options.text: An aggressive surgical approach should be avoided in the presence of distant metastases.

questions.correct_answer: D. An aggressive surgical approach should be avoided in the presence of distant metastases.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

An aggressive surgical approach should be avoided in the presence of distant metastases. Non-functioning Endocrine Pancreatic Tumors are relatively large BUT have better resectability and excellent long-term survival compared with their exocrine counterparts. An aggressive surgical approach should be CONSIDERED in malignant NF-PETs, even in the presence of distant metastases.

Highyeild:

Adjuvant treatment is not given if no visible metastatic disease is detected, even if CgA levels are still high. Debulking surgery for locally advanced or metastatic pNETs is controversial due to favorable survival without surgery. In fit patients with pNET in the head of the pancreas and minimal liver disease, pancreaticoduodenectomy with wedge resection may be appropriate to avoid morbidity before death from metastatic disease. Cytoreductive surgery in metastatic pNET is controversial, but aggressive resection of the primary tumor, regional lymph nodes, and liver/distant metastases should be pursued if more than 90% of the tumor burden can be removed.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . The major goal is a potentially curative resection. Curative resections are possible in up to 62% of cases. Option: B. Repeated resections for resectable recurrences or metastases are justified to improve survival. Option: C. Partial Pancreaticoduodenectomy is usually performed, as well as the SYNCHRONOUS or METACHRONOUS resection of liver metastases.

Extraedge:

Treatment can include cytoreductive surgery, directed therapy for liver metastases, and systemic medical therapy. Local ablative therapies such as RFA, cryotherapy, microwave coagulation, and ethanol injection can be performed percutaneously or during surgery and have been shown to complement the resection of primary tumors and liver metastases.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent abdominal pain & diarrhea to the clinic and was evaluated for the same. He also had symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease. On endoscopy, fulminating ulcer diathesis in the duodenum was seen. His Gastrin levels were 1100 pg/mL. What is the best course of treatment if a duodenal Gastrinoma measuring 7 mm is detected in the patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Tumor excised with Full thickness Excision.

questions.correct_answer: C. Tumor excised with Full thickness Excision.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tumor excised with Full thickness Excision. The duodenum should be opened with a longitudinal incision and the posterior and anterior walls palpated separately. Duodenal tumors smaller than 5 mm can be enucleated with the overlying mucosa. Whereas, larger tumors are excised with full-thickness excision of the duodenal wall. Larger tumors, >5 mm in size, are excised with full-thickness excision of the duodenal wall.

Highyeild:

With elevated Gastrin levels, and the presence of a 7 mm duodenal gastrinoma, the patient is likely suffering from Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES). PPIs can effectively control acid secretion, eliminating the need for total gastrectomy and other acid-reducing surgeries. In cases of ZES in MEN-1, hyperparathyroidism should be treated first and neck exploration performed before removing the gastrinoma. Distal pancreatectomy is used to treat gastrinomas in the body or tail of the pancreas. Pancreaticoduodenectomy is the treatment of choice for gastrinomas located in the head of the pancreas.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Pancreaticoduodenectomy is done for Pancreatic Gastrinoma with MEN 1 syndrome. As recurrence is usually duodenal. Option: B. Enucleation with overlying mucosa excision is done for tumors <5mm in size Option: D . Chemotherapy with Streptozocin, 5-FU, and Octreotide is only done in case a tumor is unresectable or metastases have occurred.

Extraedge:

The presence of liver metastases is the best predictor of survival for patients with gastrinoma. Lymph node metastases are not predictive of survival for these patients. Resection of all gross disease and metastases may help with symptom relief and prolong survival in some cases.

questions.text: Neuroendocrine tumors can be present in various locations in the body. Arrange the following according to the highest percentage to the lowest percentage: LUNGS. COLON. SMALL BOWEL. APPENDIX. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D>C>A>B The pancreas is the most common site for NETs (about 30% of cases). The lungs are the second most common site (about 25% of cases). NETs of the small intestine account for about 20% of cases. NETs of the rectum account for about 10% of cases. The relative distribution of NETs can vary depending on the organ involved.

Highyeild:

The relative distribution of NET in different organ Site Distribution (%) Lung 10 Stomach 5 Duodenum 2 Small bowel 25 Appendix 40 Colon 6 Rectum 15

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option: A . Lung represents 10% of the NET distribution. Option: B. Colon represents 6% of the NET distribution. Option: C. Small bowel represents 25% of the NET distribution. Option: D. Appendix represents 40% of the NET distribution.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman was found to have chronic atrophic gastritis on a routine endoscopy. Her blood investigations came back with RAISED GASTRIN. There were 3 lesions seen, all ~0.5cm in size. She is asymptomatic, as of now. Histopathology of a growth removed from the stomach was found to be, BENIGN, NON-FUNCTIONAL, & WELL DIFFERENTIATED. What is the best course of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic resection. Type 1 tumors (ECLomas) are the most frequent NET of the stomach (approximately 80%); they occur mostly in elderly women. The histological pattern in TYPE 1 is Benign, non-functional, and well differentiated. Endoscopic resection is the treatment of choice. Antrectomy and resection of ECLomas should be undertaken only if : There is a recurrent disease, Multiple (more than six) tumors, At least one measuring >1 cm and Infiltration of at least one into the submucosa.

Highyeild:

Type I: Associated with atrophic gastritis, high pH, and gastrin levels. Types I and II come from ECL cells. Local excision of Type I polyps > 10 mm is an absolute indication for surgery.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Criteria for Antrectomy & resection not fulfilled. Option: C . Most are benign. Gastrectomy is done for TYPE 3. Option: D . Radical Surgery is done in TYPE 4 disease.

Extraedge:

TYPE 1 ( 70-80% ) are usually discovered during the gastroscopy performed to investigate non-specific digestive symptoms.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with recurrent abdominal pain came to the OPD with sudden painful reddening of the face and chest [flushing], along with wheezing & coughing. She was also found to have RAISED 5-HIAA in a 24-hour urine sample. Which of the following cardiac abnormalities are LEAST likely to be seen in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitral Regurgitation. The given case scenario is that of a Neuroendocrine Tumor with Carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid syndrome presents with the collective symptoms of sudden painful reddening of the face and chest (‘flushing’), diarrhea, or bronchospasm. About 60% of patients eventually develop cardiac symptoms because of stenosis and insufficiency of the pulmonary and, more rarely, the tricuspid valve, with enlargement and thickening of the wall of the right atrium. The etiology is unknown but local effects of serotonin and kinins may contribute. Cardiac lesions commonly involve the right side of the heart, & left-sided lesions are present only in 15% of patients. The three most common cardiac lesions are pulmonary stenosis (90%), tricuspid insufficiency (47%), and tricuspid stenosis (42%). The mitral valve being at the left heart is less commonly involved than others.

Highyeild:

When Neuroendocrine Tumors metastasizes to the liver, "carcinoid syndrome" can occur. The syndrome presents with symptoms such as reddish-blue cyanosis, flushing attacks, diarrhea, borborygmi, asthmatic attacks, and eventually pulmonary and tricuspid stenosis. Alcohol can induce flushing attacks in carcinoid syndrome.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Pulmonary stenosis is seen in 90% of cases of cardiac involvement. Option: B. Tricuspid Insufficiency is seen in 47% of cases of cardiac involvement. Option: C. Tricuspid Stenosis is seen in 42% of cases of cardiac involvement.

Extraedge:

Surgical resection for liver metastases is an option if no extrahepatic metastases, liver function is not compromised, and no diffuse bilobar involvement The recurrence rate for liver metastasectomy is high at 75% Transarterial chemoembolization or radioembolization can control disease Resection of primary tumor improves survival and slows the progression of hepatic metastases Hepatic transplantation has high recurrence rates and limited use

questions.text: Following an Octreotide (SRS) scan of a patient with a neuroendocrine tumor of the gut, which was done for the planning of the surgical/medical management in this patient. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgery should be deferred in the presence of liver metastases.

options.label: B
options.text: Resection of large amounts of the bowel (100 cm or more).

options.label: C
options.text: Somatostatin & its analogs provide symptomatic treatment of the ‘carcinoid’ syndrome.

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery is done for resection of the primary tumor and mesenteric lymph node metastases.

questions.correct_answer: A. Surgery should be deferred in the presence of liver metastases.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgery should be deferred in the presence of liver metastases. The diagnosis of NET of the small bowel is made by history, physical examination of the abdomen, imaging, and an assessment of 5-HIAA in a 24-hour urine sample. Surgery should be undertaken as soon as the diagnosis is made, even in the presence of liver metastases. In the presence of liver metastases, the extrahepatic disease should be resected whenever possible.

Highyeild:

Intestine embryology from the foregut, midgut, and hindgut Bronchus and lungs also developed from the foregut APUD neuroendocrine cells found in these tissues play a vital role in intestinal motility and secretion Different neuroendocrine markers secreted by all cells such as synaptophysin, chromogranin A, and neuron-specific enolase Peptide hormones produced and stored in granules, including serotonin, somatostatin, PP, and gastrin Chromogranin A used as a tumor marker in clinical practice Serotonin metabolite 5-HIAA in urine is the primary functional test for NETs of jejunum and ileum

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Resection of large amounts of the bowel (100 cm or more), particularly if stage III or IV lymph node masses are found in the mesentery Option: C. Somatostatin and its analogs provide symptomatic treatment of the ‘carcinoid’ syndrome caused by a large volume of liver metastases. These drugs also have an antiproliferative effect. Option: D. The main goal is resection of the bowel primary tumor(s) and mesenteric lymph node metastases

Extraedge:

Indications of surgery include: Local excision is used for type I polyps larger than 10mm Visualized gastrinoma treated Type III gastric NET treated.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man came to the emergency department with severe intermittent watery diarrhea. He was weak, dehydrated, and was found to have hypokalemia. Under suspicion, a CT scan was done, which shows a 5cm size mass in the Pancreas of the patient. Which of the following pancreatic endocrine tumors is most likely to be a cause for this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VIPoma. The presentation is that of WDHA syndrome , which is seen in VIPoma. Watery diarrhea , hypokalaemia , achlorhydria (WDHA) syndrome, or pancreatic cholera . The CLASSIC clinical syndrome associated with this pancreatic endocrine neoplasm consists of severe intermittent watery diarrhea leading to dehydration, and weakness from fluid and electrolyte losses. Large amounts of potassium are lost in the stool. VIPoma presents with WDHA syndrome.

Highyeild:

Also called WDHA syndrome or pancreatic cholera. Usually found in the tail of the pancreas . About two-thirds of cases are malignant. Diagnostic triad : secretory diarrhea, high levels of circulating VIP, and pancreatic tumor. Profuse , watery , and iso osmotic diarrhea is the most common symptom. Characterized by hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, hypochlorhydria, and hyperglycemia.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Insulinoma Presents with Whipple’s triad. Option: B . Glucagonoma presents with Diabetes mellitus and Dermatitis. Option: D . Gastrinoma presents with the Zollinger-Ellison Triad.

Extraedge:

Aggressive preoperative hydration and electrolyte correction are important. Octreotide is often used to reduce diarrhea and aid in fluid replacement. Surgery is the only curative treatment for VIPomas, glucagonomas, somatostatinomas, and nonfunctional pancreatic NETs.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man came to the Surgery OPD with complaints of pain in the abdomen and with features of carcinoid syndrome. His 5-HIAA in a 24-hour urine sample was raised. What could be the causes of Abdominal symptoms in this patient? Lymph node metastasis pressing on the mesenteric arteries. Blocked appendix due to the tumor. Constriction of Mesenteric Arteries. Fibrosis of Mesentery. Obstruction of the bowel lumen. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 The raised 5-HIAA in 24Hr urine sample and the classical presentation points towards a Neuroendocrine Tumor. The abdominal symptoms can be caused by: Lymph node metastasis obstructing the mesenteric arteries. Obstructed appendix due to the tumor. Constriction of Mesenteric Arteries. Fibrosis of Mesentery. Obstruction of the bowel lumen.

Highyeild:

Clinical presentation Chronic abdominal pain is common as the first symptom. Carcinoid syndrome appears in 20-30% with liver metastases. Involved lymph node metastases cause small bowel ischemia leading to pain and diarrhea by constricting the mesenteric vessels. Statement 1. Obstruction of the mesentery by the growth of lymph node metastases in the mesentery near the bowel Statement 2. Obstruction of the appendix by an appendiceal NET can lead to appendectomy. Statement 3. Chronic Bowel Ischemia can be caused by Constriction of Mesenteric Arteries. Statement 4. Chronic Bowel Ischemia can be caused by Fibrosis of The Mesentery by a so-called desmoplastic reaction. Statement 5. Obstruction of the bowel lumen by the growth of lymph node metastases in the mesentery near the bowel.

Extraedge:

Chromogranin A often elevated, non-specific Elevated 24-hour urinary 5-HIAA is specific CT/MRI shows mesenteric lymph nodes with spiraling vessels, and detect liver metastases The biopsy is diagnostic, and Ki-67 grading is important for prognosis CT/MRI followed by 68Ga-DOTATOC PET to find the primary tumor Evaluate for Hedinger syndrome (right heart valve fibrosis)
